title: 106_hr1969
content: The "Arizona National Forest Improvement Act of 1999" defines terms like "City" as Sedona, Arizona, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture. It also addresses the sale or exchange of administrative sites. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange National Forest System land and administrative sites, including the Camp Verde Administrative Site, Cave Creek Administrative Site, Fredonia Duplex Housing Site, and Fredonia Housing Site. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange National Forest System land and administrative sites, including various sites like Groom Creek, Payson, and Sedona Administrative Sites. Consideration for the sale or exchange may include land acquisition and improvements as per the Secretary's specifications. Any transactions are subject to applicable laws. The Secretary can sell or exchange National Forest System land under specific laws and regulations. Cash equalization payments exceeding 25% of the land value may be accepted. Offers for land sale or exchange can be solicited and rejected if deemed inadequate. Upon land conveyance, any public revocations are allowed. Upon conveyance of land by the Secretary, any public order withdrawing the land is revoked. SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE TO CITY OF SEDONA. The Secretary may sell approximately 300 acres of land to the city of Sedona, Arizona for an effluent disposal system. The city must pay fair market value for the land as determined by an appraisal. The City of Sedona, Arizona must pay the cost of the land appraisal and the determined amount for the land in full within 180 days or in 7 annual installments with interest accruing from the date of conveyance. The City of Sedona, Arizona must pay for the land appraisal and determined amount within 180 days or in 7 annual installments with interest. Upon conveyance, the City must hold the United States harmless from any claims to the land, and the conveyance is subject to a right of reentry if the City fails to comply with requirements or conditions set by the Secretary. The conveyed land must not be used for effluent disposal in Yavapai County, Arizona. The Secretary will deposit proceeds from sales or exchanges under the Act into the fund established under the Sisk Act. These funds can be used for acquiring, constructing, or improving administrative facilities for several national forests in Arizona, or for acquiring land or interests in land in the state.
